content:
- This occured whilst being offline in the PC-Client.

I don't think I can follow exactly what you did and why. In any case, to avoid problems in the future, do not edit a message offline which already exists on the server. The server will override your offline changes the next time you get online again. This is how IMAP works.

content: I'd suggest you make yourself familiar with how the IMAP protocol works. As said before, do not attempt to edit messages which exist on the server while being offline. You can copy messages to your 'Local Folders' account though, and safely edit them while offline. You can then upload those messages to the server once online again.

content: Was this a POP or IMAP account? If IMAP, you may need to ask Virgin Media to restore from a backup. If POP, you may find fragments on your PC, depending on whatever outage you experienced. Profiles, even old ones, are generally at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.

creator: johnmarris

content:
Just guessing but... Sounds like it's loading wicked slow, and takes time to replace the folders label.

I have seen where a disk had bad sectors and thunderbird just happened to be loaded in some of them, so it acted weird.

I'd first do a few things to the computer, to be sure it's OK.

Run a chkdsk /f/x/r to fix and replace bad sectors in an Admin Command Prompt. This takes a while to run. Then check for and install Windows updates. Then run sfc /scannow in an Admin Command Prompt - This checks and fixes windows files.

After you're sure the system is working fine, do a search for "Thunderbird Repair". There is a page to help find possible solutions there.

content:
I am just guessing here, but seeing as the LONG list of emails is dated back to 2021, and the other emails are dated 2023, then You are deleting and organizing through Thunderbird, but it's an IMAP folder on the domain, so all the emails might actually still be there in the folder. I am surprised you haven't gotten an email from the host saying you email account is near full.

You may have to actually;

1. Log into the email servers account to delete all of the emails you thought you deleted through Thunderbird, and while at it check the other folders there. Sometimes there are folders on the email servers that aren't shown through Thunderbird.

2. Control what happens when you delete an email through Thunderbird. Go to ACCOUNT SETTINGS - SERVER SETTINGS under your email account in Thunderbird and look for When I delete a message: I set this to "Move it to this folder" and set the folder to "Trash on ~MyEmailsTrashFolder~. But you will have to empty that from time to time.

Have you emptied your folder called "Deleted"?

3. You are keeping a lot of folders in your email account. That's good if you need to access them from anywhere and any system. I only need to access then from my Home computer after a while, so I create LOCAL folders for organization and drag them off the server and save them locally. This reduces my need to get online.

You seem better than me at limiting the # of folders too. Good Job haha. I JUST created a NEW Profile to clean up things...

Having everything saved locally, seems to make Thunderbird faster for me too, as I don't have to go online to see them. But, as I said, if you need access from multiple devices, you need to keep them at the email server.

Hope you figure it out...

Good Luck!!!
creator: Chicks_Hate_Me

content: Some IMAP providers have dedicated folders for use that cannot be removed. They are generally harmless and success in removing them might compromise the email service. However, you never mentioned the names of the folders; knowing that may cause a better response to appear here.

content:
By default, editing has to be manually set on a per calendar basis. The exception is the super admin role, which can edit everything. In Google, only the people listed under the "Share this calendar" section with "Manage sharing and edit events" permissions can update that calendar's events

Regards, Will

content:
Generally, you need to have the option set to allow cookies. And I always suggest NOT including password when setting up the account. And use OAUTH2. If all goes well, Google will immediately pop up a request to login to Gmail. Once that happens, Google will update the Thunderbird password with a unique passcode that applies explicitly to you and the PC and the account. That is, it will be a password that is useless anywhere else.

And, uh... if this works, I think I'm entitled to two shots of George Dickel.
creator: davidsk

content:
You may want to check your allowance of 3rd party apps in your Google Security. Recent changes in Google made me have to go back in and re-enable Thunderbird there.

Go to "myaccount.google.com" Click on the SECURITY Link. Look for "Your connections to third-party apps & services".

It should show "Mozilla Thunderbird Email"

If it doesn't, you need to add it.

content: Are you sure you're dragging from an address book to a mailing list, and not to another address book? The way it normally works, and works on my setup, is that when a contact is added to a mailing list by drag and drop, it's added to the list, but remains in the address book. If a contact is dragged from one address book to another, the contact is moved, i.e. it is removed from the source and added to the target. Holding Ctrl while dragging and dropping will copy the contact, not move it.
creator: sfhowes

content: Nope. Doing it as you say, dragging with a left click, places it in the mailing list AND removes it from the main personal address book. I am not holding down any key and am using the left mouse button.

content:
If the emails marked as SPAM are in a spam folder directly under your email, then that's a spam folder on the emails server and probably being marked there, on the email server, and not by Thunderbird.

So you may want to go to the source of the emails and check and see if they're already marked as spam there.

While there, you could WHITE LIST the specific email addresses you know are not spam, so the email server won't mark them as SPAM.

Each email account provider may have different ways of setting up a WHITE LIST, and you may also be able to adjust the sensitivity to the spam. For instance, some email hosts use spam filters like SpamAssassin where you can adjust setting. Thunderbird has a setting to Trust junk mail headers set by..." and you get to enable/disable it as well as select the type of headers it looks for.

You may want to read this... docs.cpanel.net/cpanel/email/spam-filters/

But, as I mentioned, each email service will probably be different.

Spammers Byte. They make us work too hard, forcing us to read through all the junk anyway, just to see if we missed something important.

Good Luck!!
creator: Chicks_Hate_Me

content:
Is this still an issue? Around the date you asked the question 123-reg were changing over their email servers, not just a server swap but a migration to a new email service. My understanding is email accounts from the old service are being migrated to the new service. Between old servers and new servers, server settings POP, IMAP, SMTP are changing (I am unsure if the change affected user passwords).

Using a browser, can you login to 123-reg webmail directly? If so check which service you are using and check you have the correct settings for this service.

If you need to re-configure Thunderbird for a new service, you may need to re-post as a new queary, to correctly understand how to move your account, and Thunderbird settings, forward.
